data.name: APOLOGIZE
data.value: To lay the foundation for a future offence.

data.name: APPEAL
data.value: In law, to put the dice into the box for another throw.

data.name: BAROMETER
data.value: An ingenious instrument which indicates what kind of weather we are having.

data.name: BOTANY
data.value: The science of vegetables -- those that are not good to eat, as well as those that are. It deals largely with their flowers, which are commonly badly designed, inartistic in color, and ill-smelling.

data.name: CALAMITY
data.value: A more than commonly plain and unmistakable reminder that the affairs of this life are not of our own ordering. Calamities are of two kinds: misfortune to ourselves, and good fortune to others.

data.name: QUICKSTART
data.value:
This document describes the steps needed to make and preview a simple "Hello, world!" document using the ComponentOne Preview for .NET suite of components.
<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><> Quick Start <><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>
To make a "Hello, World!" document and preview it, follow these steps:
- Create a new C# or VB.NET Windows application, call it HelloWorld.
- Open the form designer of the main app's form.
- Because the print preview is usually a quite large control, resize the form to make it larger, approx. 600 by 400 pixels.
- Add NuGet reference to C1.Win.Printing package.
- At this point, you should have the following new items in your toolbox: - C1PrintDocument - C1PreviewPane - C1PrintPreviewControl - C1PrintPreviewDialog - C1PreviewThumbnailView - C1PreviewOutlineView - C1PreviewTextSearchPanel
- Click on C1PrintPreviewControl and drop it onto your form. A print preview control with the preview pane, navigation and text search panels, and toolbar should appear on your form, called "c1PrintPreviewControl1". Go to the properties browser, and set its Dock property to Fill.
- Run your app, to make sure that the (empty) print preview appears on the form.
- Back in the designer, drop a C1PrintDocument from the toolbox onto your form. The new component will by default be called c1PrintDocument1.
- Now, go to the c1PrintPreviewControl1's properties, and set its Document property to the newly added c1PrintDocument1 (which should show up in the Document property's dropdown list). This will show that document in the preview at runtime.
- In the designer, double click on the form's title bar, to create a handler for the form load event. In that event handler, write the following lines of code:
c1PrintDocument1.Body.Children.Add( new C1.C1Preview.RenderText(c1PrintDocument1, "Hello, World!")); c1PrintDocument1.Generate();
- Run your application. The preview should show the document consisting of one page, with the words "Hello World!".
- That's it!
Note that you can manipulate the document in the preview. E.g. you can open the page setup dialog, and change the paper orientation. Clicking OK will regenerate the document in the landscape orientation. You can also adjust the margins by dragging a margin with the mouse in the preview's ruler area.
<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><> The End. <><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>
